meta.title: How Charged Is Your Parenting Battery Right Now?
meta.description: A quick check on your energy, patience, emotional reserves, and connection quality. Not about your kid. About you. Because you can't pour from an empty battery.
meta.intro: This isn't about whether your kid is hitting milestones. It's a honest snapshot of how you're holding up right now — your energy, your patience reserves, and whether you're running on fumes or something closer to a full charge.
meta.subject: you
meta.shareCta: Curious about your own parenting battery level?

previewCta.eyebrow: Want to see the full picture?
previewCta.title: Get your complete parenting battery profile

questions.text: How does your body feel by the time the kids are in bed?
questions.subtext: Not emotionally. Physically. Bones, muscles, eyelids.

options.text: I still have gas in the tank — could do a load of laundry or read a chapter without falling asleep
Tired but functional — I can get one more thing done if I push through
I am a husk. I collapse on the couch and stare at my phone because I have nothing left

questions.text: How well are you sleeping, realistically?
questions.subtext: Not how many hours you're in bed. How rested you actually feel.

options.text: Getting enough sleep and waking up reasonably human
Sleep is choppy or short, but I can mostly function
I am running a permanent sleep deficit and everything suffers because of it

questions.text: When your child does something annoying for the fourth time today, what happens inside you?
questions.subtext: The repeated shoe-throwing, the whining, the sibling poking. The fourth time.

options.text: I can still respond calmly — annoyed, sure, but I have bandwidth to handle it
I feel my patience fraying but can usually keep my voice level
I snap. Or I want to hide in the bathroom. Or both.

questions.text: How often do you feel resentful about the amount of parenting labor you carry?
questions.subtext: The invisible load — planning, tracking, anticipating, managing.

options.text: Rarely — the distribution feels manageable right now
Sometimes — it flares up but doesn't dominate my thinking
Constantly — the imbalance is a steady background hum of frustration

questions.text: In the last week, how many moments with your child actually felt good?
questions.subtext: Not survived. Not tolerated. Actually enjoyed.

options.text: Multiple — we had real moments of genuine connection and fun
A few — scattered between the logistics and the chaos
Honestly struggling to name one that wasn't just getting through the day

questions.text: When your child wants to show you something (a drawing, a bug, a 47th somersault), how do you feel?
questions.subtext: The bids for attention that come twelve times an hour.

options.text: I can genuinely engage most of the time — even if briefly
I fake interest sometimes but can still show up for the big moments
I feel touched out and mentally elsewhere — responding is a performance

questions.text: If you had a truly terrible parenting day, who would you call?
questions.subtext: Not for advice. Just to say "today was awful" and be heard.

options.text: I have at least one person who gets it and I'd actually reach out to them
I have people in my life, but I probably wouldn't call — I'd just tough it out
I don't have anyone who really understands, or I wouldn't burden them

questions.text: How often are you eating actual meals (not your kid's leftover crusts standing at the counter)?
questions.subtext: Sitting down, food you chose, reasonably nourishing.

options.text: Most days I eat real meals and stay reasonably hydrated
I eat, but it's often rushed, random, or whatever's left
I regularly forget to eat or survive on coffee and scraps until dinner

questions.text: In the last two weeks, have you done anything that was just for you?
questions.subtext: Not errands. Not "self-care" that's actually household management. Something you wanted to do.

options.text: Yes — I made time for something I actually enjoy, even if it was small
I can think of one thing, but it felt stolen rather than planned
I genuinely cannot remember the last time I did something purely for myself

questions.text: How do you feel about asking for help with the kids?
questions.subtext: From a partner, family member, friend, or paid help.

options.text: I ask when I need it and don't feel guilty about it
I can ask, but there's always a side of guilt or feeling like I should handle it myself
Asking for help feels impossible — either nobody's available or I can't bring myself to do it

high.headline: Tank isn't empty
high.detail: You're managing to keep your physical needs on the radar despite the constant demands. Your body is getting enough fuel and rest to actually function, which is less common than you'd think in the parenting trenches.
high.strength: Your physical baseline is solid right now. You're eating, sleeping enough to function, and your body isn't running on cortisol alone. This is the foundation everything else sits on.

medium.headline: Running on partial charge
medium.detail: You're functional but operating below your baseline. Sleep, food, or physical rest is getting squeezed. It's manageable for now, but this is the zone where one bad night tips you into survival mode.
medium.concern: Your physical reserves are thin enough that small disruptions — a sick kid, a bad night — hit harder than they should. Shore up one basic need this week: sleep, food, or movement.

low.headline: Body is shouting
low.detail: Your physical tank is genuinely empty. You're running on adrenaline and habit, and your body is paying the tab. This isn't sustainable, and it's affecting your capacity for everything else.
low.concern: This is the area that needs attention first. You cannot think clearly, regulate emotions, or connect with your kids when your body is in survival mode. One concrete change to sleep, food, or rest — this week.

high.headline: Patience reserves intact
high.detail: You have emotional bandwidth right now. You can absorb the daily provocations without losing your composure, and resentment isn't dominating the background. This is genuinely hard to maintain — acknowledge it.
high.strength: You're responding rather than reacting most of the time. Your emotional reserves let you stay present through the irritating stuff without it poisoning your whole day.

medium.headline: Patience is rationed
medium.detail: You're managing your emotional output carefully, like budgeting a limited resource. Some moments get your best, others get your leftovers. The resentment or irritability is noticeable but not constant.
medium.concern: Your emotional reserves are being spent faster than they're refilling. Notice which situations drain you fastest — those are where you need a plan, not just willpower.

low.headline: Emotional tank is dry
low.detail: You're regularly hitting the bottom of your patience and emotional capacity. Snapping, withdrawing, or feeling constantly resentful are signals that you've been running a deficit for too long.
low.concern: When emotional reserves are this low, everything feels personal and every demand feels unfair. This isn't a character flaw — it's depletion. Reducing one source of emotional drain matters more right now than adding a coping strategy.

high.headline: Still enjoying them
high.detail: Despite the chaos, you're still finding genuine moments of connection with your kids. You can engage with their bids for attention without feeling like you're performing. That matters more than most parenting advice gives it credit for.
high.strength: Your capacity to be present and actually enjoy your child is intact. Kids feel the difference between a parent who's there and a parent who's going through the motions — and yours feels you there.

medium.headline: Connection is spotty
medium.detail: You have good moments, but they're inconsistent. Some days you're genuinely present, other days you're physically there but mentally checked out. The autopilot stretches are getting longer.
medium.concern: Connection doesn't require marathon play sessions — it needs 5-minute pockets of genuine attention. One fully-present interaction per day does more than an hour of half-distracted togetherness.

low.headline: Going through the motions
low.detail: The daily grind has pushed real connection to the margins. You're managing logistics and behavior but struggling to find moments that actually feel good. Your child's bids for attention feel like one more demand on an empty account.
low.concern: When connection drops this low, guilt usually fills the gap — and guilt is not a useful parenting fuel. Start with one micro-moment: 2 minutes of undivided attention, no agenda, no teaching. Let it be small.

high.headline: Support system is working
high.detail: You have people to lean on, you're doing things for yourself, and asking for help doesn't feel like a moral failing. This is the infrastructure that keeps everything else from collapsing.
high.strength: You've built or maintained a support network that actually functions. You're also giving yourself permission to have needs — which sounds basic but is remarkably hard for parents to sustain.

medium.headline: Support exists but underused
medium.detail: You have some support structures, but you're not fully using them. Whether it's guilt, logistics, or habit, you're carrying more alone than you need to. The safety net is there but has holes.
medium.concern: The support exists — the barrier is using it. Pick one thing you've been doing alone and delegate or ask for help with it this week. Not as a permanent fix, just as a trial.

low.headline: Flying solo
low.detail: You're operating without a functional support system — either the people aren't there, or you can't bring yourself to use them. Self-care has become a theoretical concept rather than something that actually happens.
low.concern: Isolation compounds every other problem on this list. One connection — a text to a friend, joining a parent group, accepting an offer of help — breaks the pattern. It doesn't have to be big. It has to be real.

fully-charged.headline: Fully Charged
fully-charged.subheadline: Your energy, emotional reserves, connection, and support systems are all holding up — which means you're parenting from a place of capacity rather than survival.
fully-charged.explanation: A high battery doesn't mean parenting is easy or that you never lose it. It means you have enough in the tank to recover when things go sideways. You're sleeping enough to think straight, eating something besides goldfish crackers, and you have at least one person who gets it. That infrastructure lets you show up as the parent you actually want to be — most days.
nextSteps: Protect what's working — identify the 2-3 habits or structures that keep your battery charged and defend them ruthlessly
Use your surplus capacity to build in a buffer for hard stretches — meal prep, backup childcare plans, or a standing date with a friend
Notice what drains you fastest and build a boundary around that specific thing
fully-charged.watchOutFor: A full battery can create a "push through" mentality where you take on more because you can handle it. That's how batteries go from full to empty without warning. Sustainable beats heroic.
fully-charged.encouragement: You're in a solid place right now. That didn't happen by accident, and it won't maintain itself by accident either. Keep doing whatever you're doing to stay resourced.
fully-charged.comparativeContext: Research on parental burnout shows that parents who maintain basic self-care routines are 3-4 times less likely to reach clinical burnout thresholds, even during high-stress phases.

half-charged.headline: Running Low
half-charged.subheadline: You're functional but stretched thin — some areas are holding up while others are quietly draining. This is the zone where small interventions prevent a bigger crash.
half-charged.explanation: Most parents live here. You're getting through the days, the kids are fed and alive, but you can feel the margin getting thinner. Some domains are fine while others are running a deficit. The danger isn't today — it's the accumulation. Two months of "fine but tired" eventually becomes "I can't do this anymore." The good news: you're not there yet, and targeted changes in your lowest domain can shift the whole picture.
nextSteps: Look at your domain breakdown and find the one scoring lowest — that's your highest-leverage target
Make one concrete change this week in that domain, not five aspirational ones
Tell someone specific how you're doing — not "fine" but the actual answer
Block out 30 minutes this week that belongs only to you, and treat it like a doctor's appointment
half-charged.watchOutFor: The middle zone feels manageable, which makes it easy to ignore. But batteries don't send a warning at 20% — they just die. Don't wait for a crisis to address what's draining you.
half-charged.encouragement: You're not in crisis and you're not thriving. That's honest. The most useful thing you can do right now is pick one area and make it slightly better. Not perfect. Just better.
half-charged.comparativeContext: The majority of parents score in this range. Studies on parental well-being show that targeted improvements in the lowest-scoring area produce measurable gains across all domains within 2-3 weeks.

running-on-fumes.headline: Running on Fumes
running-on-fumes.subheadline: Your battery is critically low across multiple areas. You're surviving, not functioning — and that's not a personal failing, it's a resource problem.
running-on-fumes.explanation: When the battery is this low, everything feels harder than it should. Patience evaporates, connection feels like a performance, and self-care sounds like a cruel joke told by someone with a nanny. You're not broken — you're depleted. The instinct is to push harder, but that's like pressing the accelerator on an empty tank. Something has to change structurally, not just attitudinally.
nextSteps: This is not a willpower problem — identify one structural change (sleep, help, reducing a commitment) and make it happen this week
Tell your partner, a friend, or your doctor the truth about how you're doing. The actual truth, not the curated version.
Lower your standards temporarily and deliberately — frozen pizza, screen time, messy house. Survival mode gets different rules.
If this has been your baseline for more than a month, talk to a healthcare provider about burnout screening
running-on-fumes.watchOutFor: When the battery is this low, guilt becomes the dominant emotion — and guilt drives you to give more, which drains you further. That cycle doesn't break with effort. It breaks with help.
running-on-fumes.encouragement: The fact that you took this quiz means some part of you is paying attention to how you're doing. That matters. You don't need to overhaul your life. You need one thing to change. Start there.
running-on-fumes.comparativeContext: Parental burnout research identifies this level of depletion as a risk factor for chronic stress symptoms. Most parents who implement even one structural change report measurable improvement within two weeks.
